intro: Afrosciadium lundense, commonly known as the African mountain spinach, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of East Africa. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in forested areas at elevations above 1,500 meters. Afrosciadium lundense is valued for its edible leaves, which are used in local cuisines and have a mild, spinach-like flavor.
